snippet: The number of people who have locked themselves away, either under government orders or voluntarily, has grown well beyond those who lived with and cared for the first Ebola victim in Dallas.
abstract: Number of people who have locked themselves away due to Ebola, some under government order and others voluntarily, has grown well beyond those who lived with and cared for Thomas Eric Duncan before his death; Texas officials say nearly 100 health workers will be asked to sign pledges to quarantine themselves for 21 days.

byline.original: By KEVIN SACK, JACK HEALY and FRANCES ROBLES

lead_paragraph: The number of people who have locked themselves away, either under government orders or voluntarily, has grown well beyond those who lived with and cared for the first Ebola victim in Dallas.

headline.main: Life in Quarantine for Ebola Exposure: 21 Days of Fear and Loathing
headline.print_headline: Life in Quarantine: 21 Days of Fear and Loathing
